contentrichtext.text: The '''Blaine Act''' was sponsored by [[Wisconsin]] Senator [[John J. Blaine]] and passed by the [[United States Senate]] on February 17, 1933. It initiated the repeal of the [[Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]], which established [[Prohibition in the United States]]. The repeal was formally adopted as the [[Twenty-first Amendment to the United States Constitution|21st Amendment to the Constitution]] on December 5, 1933. ==References== *[http://www.wisconsinhistory.org/wlhba/articleView.asp?pg=2&id=436&hdl=&np=Fennimore+Times&adv=yes&ln=&fn=&q=&y1=&y2=&ci=&co=&mhd=&shd= "John J. Blaine, former US senator and governor, dies", ''Fennimore Times'', April 18, 1934] *[http://www.druglibrary.org/schaffer/Library/studies/nc/nc2a.htm "History of alcohol prohibition", National Commission on Marihuana and Drug Abuse, based in large part on a paper prepared for the Commission by Jane Lang McGrew] *[http://cgi.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/1996/analysis/back.time/9602/28/ "Prohibition: The 21st Amendment", ''TIME'', February 27, 1933] [[Category:Prohibition in the United States]] [[Category:Legal history of the United States]] [[Category:United States federal controlled substances legislation]] [[Category:1933 in law]] {{US-fed-statute-stub}}
